Pre 1900 - no tram lines.

Looking south from Bathurst Street.

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: And probably post 1880, going by the architecture of some of those buildings. If I had a trusty Sands Directory, we could probably narrow it down!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
20958381@N08
comment._content: aaaaah yes, i remember reading about that!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I think I can narrow it further to pre 1890. Compare the large size image with this 1899 photo from the Tyrrell Collection at the Powerhouse Museum which details a building (with theatrical posters for 1899) on the South East corner of George and Liverpool Streets. www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2712341239/ The building is conveniently dated 1890 on the parapet (see the Persistent URL at full zoom www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=29634 ), and appears several metres taller than the telegraph pole on the corner. That same telegraph pole is in this photo (third from the left - see note) but there is no taller corner building. Which implies this photo is before the 1890 building, if not while it was being built, 1889-90. So 1885-1890?

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: man ... you are good!

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: It's a great snapshot of the hustle and bustle of daily life in Sydney's main street pre 1890 and all your great comments have added to it's story.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Oddly enough I have no love either for this photo or this part of George Street.  It seems George Street always was an ugly mess, it is still a mess, and probably always will be messy.  Such is progress . . . 

Still trying to narrow the date further, but I am betting c.1890.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: Thanks to all the wonderful detective work here and at the Archives Outside blog we have added 1885-1890 as a date range.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: In the last year or so the rest of the SMH (to 1954) has been digitised. This might enable us to date this pic a bit more precisely. Talk about research made easy! 1) Some interesting background on this part of George Street - here's a news item on a fire which damaged the building owned by photographer Charles Lemaire (d. 1908) at 610 George St, in January 1880 - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article28390014 Here's a SMH report from 1887 on an action brought by Lemaire against his neighbour John Lawler, which indicates that Lawler had erected a building next to Lemaire's, and that this had involved the demolition of an earlier building known as Windsor House. The report also mentions that Lemaire had acquired 610 George St in 1877, had rebuilt after the 1880 fire, etc - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13650655 There was also another larger fire in this part of George St in early September 1894 which gutted Lawler's Central Emporium (the 5 story building seen here) and damaged adjoining buildings...the first url here brings up a fantastic action pic of the fire from the T&CJ - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71263718 - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article62964083 I'm a bit puzzled by the numbering of Lemaire's and Lawler's buildings. Per the various newspaper items Lemaire's photographic studio was at 610 George St (you can see the numbering on Lemaire's sign in this pic), whilst Lawler's Central Emporium was at 608 George St. If this were the case, then Lemaire's building should be on the right side of Lawler's, not the left, as appears to be the case in this pic...maybe the buildings were renumbered at some point - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13966630 It's not entirely clear, but on the odd numbered side of George Street, the shop this side of Biddel Brothers' sign might be George Guyatt & Co., surgical instrument maker. Various newspaper adverts have Guyatt's address as 495 George Street...Per the City of Sydney Assessment Book info Biddel Brothers were evidently at 505-507 - www3.photosau.com/CosRates/scripts/home.asp 2) Re dating the photo - Draper Walter Long (d. 1898) appears to have been moving from 600 George St to new premises in ca. July-August 1887...see Long's advert which appeared in the SMH in July 1887, where he is seeking new premises (column c, 8th item in 'Houses Land &tc Wanted') - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13657535 ; also see this SMH item from August 1887, where 600 George St is advertised in the 'To Let' column (bottom of column b) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13647092 ...this advert for a junior suggests that Long had moved to 327 George St by October 1888 (column d, 14th item from top) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13700509 Other items suggest that Long had moved on by February 1888 (column d, 4th item from bottom) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13676310 So, going on Beachcomber's note (above) re the ornamental verandah, it would appear that this pic was taken after the erection of the ornamental verandah 1885, but prior to Walter Long's 'removal' (to use a quaint 19th century term), which took place between ca. July-August 1887 and February 1888.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Now here's an interesting pic! ...there's also an accompanying item on p.11 - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article64035985 Note how the wall with the Biddel Brothers' sign is here in shade! Perhaps at the discretion of the artist, or maybe the sign wasn't there in late 1884 or early 1885 or whenever the artist drew this pic. Note the telephone lines! Is that the ornamental verandah under construction on the odd number side of George Street? Lawler's 5 story building, which in the photo appears to be more or less opposite Biddel Brothers...it doesn't make it into this pic...maybe it wasn't built at the time?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Golly, you are having fun with this one!  Go for it!

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Re 594 George St...the sign on the wall appears to be for Perry & Co 'flour manufacturers'. Per various digitised newspaper hits, Perry & Co appear to have moved out of 594 by early 1888 (though of course the sign might have remained there for some time afterwards). Here's an Illustrated Sydney News item from April 1888 on draper Frederic Messiter's 'Bon Marche' which had recently opened at 594 George St - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article63621055 ...I wonder why the building beside 594 is missing in the illustration...maybe this is a schematic representation...or was there a demolition? Here's a SMH item from February 1888 seeking tenders for a refit of 594 George St. This might have been for draper Frederic Messiter's 'Bon Marche' (column e, 10th from top) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13676802

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: This is interesting...SMH 20 December, 1886, p. 14...'Notice of Removal'...Lemaire's Photographic Studio...from 610 to 604 George St (column d, 'Business Announcements') - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13623246 ...OK, so Lemaire's sign in the photo shows the street number 610...so provided Lemaire kept the number on his sign up to date, then this pic must predate the move...right?...Well I'm not convinced...If you see my note above...how I was puzzled by the street number on Lemaire's building...ie how 610 could be on this side of Lawler's Central Emporium (which was numbered 608)...well what I suspect we see here is Lemaire's sign after his move to 604 (which would have been this side of Lawler's), but that he hasn't as yet got around to updating the street number on his sign...this is the simplest and arguably the best explanation for the apparent (but not actual) street number irregularity...another point to keep in mind here is that if draper Walter Long was at 600 George St, then it's difficult to see how the real 610 George St can have been almost next door...If my theory is correct (and it might not be!), then this would suggest that the photo was taken some time after Lemaire's move to 604 George St in ca. December 1886 (possibly quite soon after...he hadn't yet found time to update his street number)...but some time before draper Walter Long's removal from 600 George St, which appears to have taken place between ca. August 1887 and February 1888...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] We can see your brain working, and it looks like you were up till 2 am doing that! True dedication! I think it has paid off for you - well done! If it is late 1886 or 1887, I suggest that it is high summer due to the short shadows under the traffic, and about 11 am or noon, due to George Streets NNE alignment at this section. Google Maps Street View - the street looks much narrower now - g.co/maps/npe6w

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: SMH 24 March, 1886, p. 15 'Final Clearance Sale' (column e, 3rd item from top) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13615121 This item gives us some idea when Lawler's Central Emporium was built...here the advert states 'premises [ie. 608 George Street] to be pulled down to allow the erection of new buildings'...This explains why we can't see Lawler's Central Emporium in the January 1885 Illustrated Sydney News sketch of this part of George St (see my note above)...So I'd guess that Lawler's Central Emporium would have been built in the period from ca. April 1886 through until perhaps early 1887. Per one SMH item, Lawler continued to trade at Union Lane whilst the new building was under construction at 608 George St (notice mid way down column b) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-page1401566... However, by October 1886 he appears to have returned to 608, though I suspect that the building work might not have been completed by that point (column c, 9th from top) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13618115 ...surley it would have taken longer than the 6 months from April to October 1886 to demolish an existing structure and then erect a 6 story building. So as things stand, given Beachcomber's observations re the shadows...I'd say this photo was taken in mid-summer 1886/7 or mid-summer 1887/8, and I'd probably lean towards 1886/7.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: SMH 12 August, 1887, p. 7 (column e, 'Buisnesses for Sale') - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13646726 ...Hopsons millinery and underclothing business ('established 28 years') was up for sale at this time...it was apparently purchased by W. Kensett by September 1887 ('Wanted, junior young ladies and apprentices', column c, 19th from bottom) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13659465 ...a number of Kensett's adverts appear in the SMH from about this time, many of them with the line 'Kensett (late Hopson's) 590 George St'. Of course it is possible that Kensett continued to trade under the business name 'Hopsons', and that the Hopsons sign might have remained above the shop after the change in ownership. However from the various adverts I get the sense that this wasn't the case. So whilst you probably wouldn't want to be too emphatic, these items suggest that the photo was taken before Hopsons changed hands, ie. before ca. September 1887...which of course stacks up with the mid-summer 1886/7 date.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Some great links and research! The evidence does seem to point towards a 1886/7 date. Thanks for all your efforts!

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: OK, so now we need a suitably qualified volunteer to drive a horse and cart up and down George Street every day for a month during mid-summer, just for an hour or so from about 11.00am, until we arrive at a point when the shadows match up. Any takers?

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: If anyone is interested, there's a fantastic illustrated article in the 'Sydney Mail', 18 December, 1886 (supp. p. xxii), on the then recently opened Lawler's Central Emporium at 608 George Street. Per this article, work on the building began in January 1886 (rather than April 1886 as I'd assumed above), which suggests that 608 George Street would have been a building site for much of that year. In terms of dating the photo, the SM article doesn't add much to what has now been established, albeit via a round-about route. But if you're interested in the history of this part of George Street, or in the architecture and building engineering of 1880s Sydney, the SM article is well worth a look...hopefully you'll have more luck viewing the SM on Google News Archive than I do. I resorted to trawling thru microfilm reels!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] This link should work for the Lawler's Central Emporium - news.google.com/newspapers?id=u8JPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=U5MDA... Press the + and - buttons to zoom. Google News Archive seems to be gradually dying unfortunately. Read all about it whilst you can! www.genealogyintime.com/NewsStories/2011/Q2/the_death_of_...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Thanks Beachcomber! I didn't realise that it was possible to get a legible version by zooming beyond the scrambled eggs which appears on the first zoom. Yes, I do know how to operate a toaster!

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: In this SLNSW pic, Perry & Co's sign has either been changed or replaced...though it's difficult to tell just going on the fragment we see...so the SLNSW pic might have been taken after Perry & Co moved on...ca. early 1888...but pre the 1894 fire at Lawler's. This SLNSW pic appears in - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=401890

comment.author: 54812486@N04
comment._content: Thank you for the fascinating commentary regarding this photo. I have learnt so much thanks to your knowledge and your wiliness to share such knowledge. My husband’s great grandfather, Ernest Stranger BOND & Ernest’s brother-in-law, Frederick George PATCHING occupied the building that was completely destroyed when the wall collapsed. A small article can be seen in the New Zealand paper - paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=s.... I think it is likely that PATCHING & BOND DRAPERY was the building that was previously occupied by Walter Long Drapery. This has enabled me to narrow down my time frame of occupation

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/claudiabond] I never cease to be amazed at how much info can be ferrited out of the newspapers...and how much it can add to our knowledge of these fantastic old pics...I hope your husband's ancestors had good insurance!
